All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.

If you ever have trouble sleeping, you may need a weighted blanket in your life. The best weighted blankets wrap you up in comfort that extends well beyond warmth: The mass of a heavier blanket simulates what researchers refer to as deep pressure touch—and that gentle, deep pressure can stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system to produce endorphins and release dopamine and serotonin, which can help soothe and calm the body.

In other words, snuggling up under a weighted blanket is akin to getting a big hug.

“The data on weighted blankets has shown that for people who suffer from sleep-related anxiety or pre-bed anxiety, a 12- to 15-pound blanket can be an effective tool for helping people calm down and relax before bed,” says Michael J. Breus, PhD, a sleep expert who serves on the American Board of Sleep Medicine and the American Academy of Sleep Medicine. And restful sleep isn’t the only benefit. Weighted blankets have been reported to lessen anxiety, relieve pain, and improve overall mood.

With these potential benefits in mind, we personally tested and reviewed dozens of weighted blankets, sharing our seven top picks with you below. With plenty of styles to choose from, there's a soothing option on this list for every sleeper in need of a little extra comfort.

Best Weighted Blankets of 2024: Our Top Picks

  • Best Overall Weighted Blanket: Brooklyn Bedding Chunky Knit Weighted Blanket
  • Best Customizable Weighted Blanket: Luxome Weighted Blanket
  • Best Affordable Weighted Blanket: Nectar Serenity Weighted Blanket
  • Best Luxury Weighted Blanket: Saatva Velvet Weighted Blanket
  • Softest Weighted Blanket: Layla Weighted Blanket
  • Best Velvet Weighted Blanket: Bearaby Velvet Napper
  • Best Weighted Throw Blanket: Brooklinen Weighted Throw Blanket

Browse all seven of our top weighted blankets, or jump straight to a specific blanket below:

Brooklyn Bedding Chunky Knit Weighted Blanket | Luxome Weighted Blanket | Nectar Serenity Weighted Blanket | Saatva Velvet Weighted Blanket | Layla Weighted Blanket | Bearaby Velvet Napper | Brooklinen Weighted Throw Blanket

Best Overall Weighted Blanket: Brooklyn Bedding Chunky Knit Weighted Blanket

Brooklyn Bedding Chunky Knit Weighted Blanket

This cozy weighted blanket from Brooklyn Bedding earns our top spot because it truly has something for everyone. Our tester, a notoriously hot sleeper, found the open loops of the hand-knit construction nice and breathable. The even weight distribution of the blanket provides a subtle calming feel that works for newcomers to the world of weighted bedding, as well as those who already adore that hugging sensation from a blanket. The jersey material is also soft and smooth to the touch, a win for people with sensitive skin.

  • Materials: 100% polyester jersey
  • Weights: 10 and 15 pounds
  • Colors: Cream and gray
  • Care instructions: Spot-clean recommended (the weight of the blanket might be more than what some at-home washing machines can handle)

Best Customizable Weighted Blanket: Luxome Weighted Blanket

Luxome Weighted Blanket

Luxome makes it easy to find your perfect fit, offering its weighted blanket in two separate pieces (the insert and the cover) and one integrated blanket, as well as two Minky sides, two bamboo sides, or one of each. Our tester tried the version with the removable cover with Minky on one side and bamboo on the other, describing the Minky as luxuriously plush and the bamboo as cooling and moisture-wicking–the best of both worlds.

  • Materials: Minky and/or lyocell from bamboo with 1-millimeter glass beads fill
  • Weights: 15, 18, and 25 pounds
  • Colors: Light gray, gray, navy, and ocean
  • Care instructions: 100% machine-washable (except for XL insert)

Best Affordable Weighted Blanket: Nectar Serenity Weighted Blanket

Nectar Serenity Weighted Blanket

The only weighted blanket on our list available for under $100 (and on sale often throughout the year), the Nectar Serenity Weighted Blanket features a cooling bamboo material on one side and warming mink-like material on the other for all-season soothing. Our tester highlighted how the quilted interior that holds the fill maintains its weight distribution really well, and she was surprised to find just how well the dual-temperature design worked. Nectar’s five-year warranty is one of the best we’ve seen too.

  • Materials: Bamboo rayon and polyester with glass beads and polyester fiber fill
  • Weights: 15, 20, and 25 pounds
  • Colors: Gray, navy, and tan
  • Care instructions: Cover is machine-washable and dryer-safe

Best Luxury Weighted Blanket: Saatva Velvet Weighted Blanket

Saatva Velvet Weighted Blanket

Known for its luxury mattresses, Saatva lives up to its reputation with this velvet weighted blanket. Our tester noted how the cover feels soft and fuzzy, and because it's made with cotton, it maintains a sense of airiness and breathability too. Meanwhile, the combination of cotton and glass beads in the fill made minimal noise when they moved around beneath the blanket—always a win for lighter sleepers and those who share their sleep space. No doubt, it’s a luxe weighted blanket—with the price tag and maintenance to match.

  • Materials: 100% cotton velvet with cotton and glass beads fill
  • Weights: 12 and 20 pounds
  • Colors: Taupe and graphite
  • Care instructions: Dry clean as needed

Softest Weighted Blanket: Layla Weighted Blanket

Layla Weighted Blanket

Another two-sided weighted blanket option, this pick from Layla uses smooth cotton and a plush, mink-like fabric to suit a wider range of sleepers. Our tester reported that both sides make it one of the softest weighted blankets they’ve tried, and the fact that the entire blanket is machine-washable and dryer-safe is a major plus. We only wish it was available in more color options.

  • Materials: Cotton and polyester with micro glass bead fill
  • Weights: 15, 20, and 25 pounds
  • Colors: Gray
  • Care instructions: Machine-washable and dryer-safe

Best Velvet Weighted Blanket: Bearaby Velvet Napper

Bearaby Velvet Napper

Up your bed’s glam vibes by topping it with this velvety dream from Bearaby. It's both GRS- and Oeko-Tex certified, and it's perfect for all occasions: bedtime, naps, movie nights, and cuddles. Our tester was worried she would be too hot with the weight of it but found the blanket cool and reassuring instead. She even shared that it helped her sleep through her husband’s snoring and early wake-ups for the first time in 20 years. She loved it so much that she’s buying a second one for her daughter.

  • Materials: 100% upcycled velvet
  • Weights: 15, 20, and 25 pounds
  • Colors: Rose quartz, tourmaline, peridot, and silver topaz
  • Care instructions: Dry-cleaning recommended

Best Weighted Throw Blanket: Brooklinen Weighted Throw Blanket

Brooklinen Weighted Throw Blanket

If you plan on using your weighted blanket for living room cat naps, consider the Brooklinen Weighted Throw Blanket. Our tester appreciated how its effortlessly textured look blended into her existing decor, and while the blanket only comes in one size and weight, she found it ideal for shorter snoozes and simply relaxing on the couch. Just be mindful of its restrictive care instructions.

  • Materials: 99% cotton and 1% spandex crepe with glass beads fill
  • Weights: 12 pounds
  • Colors: Deep navy and deep alpine
  • Care instructions: Spot-clean at home

How We Chose the Best Weighted Blankets

We put all of our weighted blanket recommendations to the test—starting in our homes. Each weighted blanket has been slept under for countless naps and nights by our team to ensure we can share what you need to know about their fabric, weight, warmth, breathability, and overall feel and aesthetic. We also assessed them in our sleep lab, objectively measuring their ability to regulate temperature and how well they hold up over time after repeatedly following their cleaning instructions.

To learn more about how we test weighted blankets and other sleep accessories, check out our detailed sleep testing methodology.

What to Consider When Shopping for a Weighted Blanket

Weighted blankets come in an array of sizes, weights, and styles, which can make it challenging to pick one that adds the perfect touch of calm to your carefully curated chill space. Think about the following details as you browse our top picks to determine which weighted blanket could best suit your needs.

Weight

Naturally, the weight of a weighted blanket is a top priority. Too lightweight, and it may not evoke the soothing sensation you're searching for. Too heavy, and it may actually cause physical discomfort. Weights for these blankets tend to start around seven pounds and can exceed 30 pounds, which leaves lots of room to determine the Goldilocks fit for your body.

The rule of thumb is to pick a blanket around 10% of your body weight. Therefore, a 120-pound person should look for a 12-pound blanket, a 150-pound person a 15-pound blanket, and so on. (If your weight falls in between blanket sizes, go with the lighter one). It’s all a matter of personal preference, of course, but this formula should give you a blanket that feels just right. (With children, however, take this rule literally. If the blanket is too heavy for them, they could struggle to get out from under it, as can pets.)

Materials

Weighted blanket cover materials range from classic cotton and cooling bamboo to luxurious velvet and warming fleece, and a number of blankets feature a dual-sided design to make use of two fabrics. Similar to how you shop for bed sheets, consider how these different materials can support your personal preferences and overall comfort.

Another material to consider is the fill of the weighted blanket. Some feature glass or plastic beads, often within a quilted design, that distribute the weight of the blanket fairly evenly but can also make a bit of noise as you move around. Others are filled with fabrics and other fibers for a quieter experience. Meanwhile, knit-exclusive designs that resemble a cozy sweater are woven with heavier fabrics to achieve an even weight distribution.

Size

Weighted blanket sizes range dramatically and tend to lack the standardization we've come to know and appreciate when shopping for mattresses and other bedding. Be sure to review the dimensions of a weighted blanket before purchasing so you have a clear understanding of how it will lay across your bed or sofa.

Care Instructions

Some weighted blankets feature machine-washable removable covers that make a weekly refresh a breeze while others list dry cleaning as the preferred care method. Consider what level of maintenance works for your lifestyle when looking for the best weighted blanket for your home.

Trial Periods and Warranties

Similar to your bed frame and mattress, quality bedding and sleep accessories are investments, and we like to help you make smart ones. Pay close attention to trial period lengths with weighted blankets, as some brands let you try them out for 100 nights risk free. Similarly, some weighted blankets can come with warranties of up to five years and protect against product defects.

FAQs

What is the best kind of weighted blanket?

Based on our research, testing and reviews, we recommend the seven weighted blankets in our list based on a wide range of user preferences. For someone who enjoys the look and feel of a cable knit sweater, an option like Brooklyn Bedding's Chunky Knit Weighted Blanket is likely the best kind of weighted blanket. Meanwhile, someone who prefers a luxe, quilted vibe should consider a style like Saatva's Velvet Weighted Blanket.

Is it bad if your weighted blanket is too heavy?

There's a reason experts use the aforementioned 10% rule when it comes to weighted blankets. Using a weighted blanket that's too heavy can be problematic in a few ways, leading to overheating, joint and muscle pain, and general discomfort that disrupts rest rather than promoting it.

Is it okay to sleep with a weighted blanket every night?

Generally, weighted blankets are considered safe for nightly snoozing so long as they're sized appropriately for your body weight and don't seem to lead to any discomfort. But when in doubt, it never hurts to check in with your health care provider.
